top_comment.text:
It amazes me how even though he can't see the hallway, he manages to walk 
right down the center and not run into stuff on the sides.﻿
top_comment.author: MrSnowrocks

comments.text:
+MrSnowrocks Well think about it too, he has been blind for a long long 
time so he has the experience to walk relatively straight. :) And the cane 
to help too. I use one of those so I know what it's like. xD
comments.author: Bobbie Carter

comments.text: You learn that stuff through the years.
comments.author: Manny Calavera

comments.text:
You can do it yourself, but do it slowly. You can hear how the sound 
changes when you get closer to the walls. It's easier when it's quiet.
comments.author: Dennis Fluttershy

comments.text:
I'm guessing he can kind of hear when he gets close to the wall on either 
side so he'd just walk away a little
comments.author: Alex Yuan

comments.text:
+MrSnowrocks He doesn't always go straight, but come on, man, if you were 
blind since birth you'd probably be just as good as him. How old is he? 
50y? For him that's like riding a bicycle.

Not saying it's not amazing for a non-blind person, but it's normal for a 
long time blind person.
comments.author: NoNamer123456789

comments.text:

off eventually he will hit one side of the other.

top_comment.text:
You walked down that hallway with stuff on both sides without bumping into 
anything. I know if I was to walk with my eyes closed, there's no way i'd 
be able to keep a straight line.

Do you have really great spatial orientation? When you're walking somewhere 
new, do you mentally "draw" a map in your head? Do you memorize basic 
things like how many steps you take from one place to another? (for 
example, from an elevator to the door of an apartment)﻿

comments.text:
My cousin is friends with a blind couple. They also say the type of shoe 
you wear helps. Like hard souls can help make different noises when you 
walk past a hallway, that way you know there is a hallways/open door.
comments.author: Joseph LoPresto

comments.text: +wang78739 that's really nice
comments.author: Destan Red (DistantRed)

comments.text:
Regulations on what a door in a public place can be (at least in the US) 
are pretty strict. Round doorknobs are actually illegal in a public 
facility like this. They either need to be a pushbar, like the ones Tommy 
was dealing with, or a handle that even a person with no fingers could open.
comments.author: berbunny

comments.text:
+DistantRed
 In hong kong all of the mtr (subway/metro) stations have these bumps on 
some parts of the floor to help blind people (circle bumps= Walkway/ 
rectanglish ones= entrance and exits etc). And in every station they have a 
map with raised icons and braille so they can figure out which way to walk 
( it plays music so they can find it and also has an assistance button)
comments.author: wang78739

comments.text:
+DistantRed
Aw, good to know at least. Ima kick every door I see with that now.
comments.author: MMQuck

comments.text:
+moomooquck I just searched around the internet and it's called a "Door 
Kick Plate", it's to protect the door's finish from people kicking it open 
or closed. Which people only do if they're over-dramatic, unable to use 
arms/hands to open doors, or your hands are full, but the idea of this 
helping the blind does give some ideas for assisting blind people (like 
ground/wall braille)
comments.author: DistantRed

comments.text:
Doors in public places sometimes have metal on the bottom, I am assuming 
that is for blind people to be able to distinguish.

comments.text:
I dunno, it seems like a big part of these videos is actually how it's *not* 
sad. Tommy seems like a really cool guy, who loves life, cracks jokes and 
enjoys the simple stuff. It's maybe sad that our society doesn't make the 
world a bit easier to get around for blind people, but it seems to me that 
there's not much sad about Tommy :)
comments.author: Emily is Vlogging

top_comment.text:

any questions (considering you were in what is usually considered to be an 
"off limits" area)?﻿

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply. I was wondering if he offered help--mostly because I 
wonder what I would do if I were in his position and saw a blind dude 
wandering around (even if he were being followed by a camera man).

comments.text:
He barely said hi. He was an employee of the convention center so I don't 
think he cared much. And the big camera on my shoulder helped.

captions.text:
(girls screaming in background)
(Tommy) It is exciting, isn't it?
(tone)
(Tommy) So we just came through this hallway and there was nobody here.
So we had a meeting with YouTube and stuff. One of the private rooms.
And now it's packed. Listen to it behind. There's no way
I'm going to get through that. So I wonder what will happen
if I walk this way instead. Let's find out.
(music)
A door. Where does it go? Let's see.
(Gasp)
(silence)
What's this?
Man, it's quiet. This is like backstage at Playlist Live.
This is very cool. Right. We're still inside.
I want to know what's back here.
(laughs) Let's go for a walk.
Which way? This way?
I don't know. Let's go this way.
Let's see what happens.
See, you're supposed to walk with your stick across from you, so...
Uh oh. We'll go here. This way... right.

(scream in background)
Uh oh.
Why am I walking towards the noise? Oh, well.
We just passed one thing.
This is great back here.
Right. So there's music back here on my left.
Right behind me.
Um. Ahead of me there's just more noise.
So I walked past something where there was some people in it.
But it's very quiet back here. There's nobody back here.
Just walking behind everything, I guess.
That's try the other way.

(yelling in background)
Uh oh.
Alright so here's some music over here on the left. What's in here?
Not much. There's a guy talking.
I don't know what he's saying. Like a little dubstep or something like that.
Cool. What else is here? Come on.
(dubstep music)
Oh, careful.
I paid all this money for this. (laughs)
Hi. How are you?
Long empty halls back here.
Stuff on either side. See, look.
Boom. Boom.
(laughs)
This is great.
Ain't nobody here. Everybody is gone.
What's this? Alright it's a door.
Yeah. Alright. Want to go in?
Let's see. There's lots of people.

(Gasp)
(Crowd of people talking)
Are we back where we started?
Sounds like it. I've got activity over here.

(William) Doing a video?
(Tommy) How are you?
(William) Oh, cool.

(Tommy) Yeah, man.
(William) Yeah.
(Tommy) What's your name?

(William) Um, my name is William.
(Tommy) Hey William. How are you? Come here. Give me some.

(Tommy) What's up man?
(William) Not much, man.
(Tommy) What are you doing?

(William) I'm just chillin', meeting everybody, you know.
(Tommy) Who have you met so far?

(William) I've met Lucas and Jenny.
(Tommy) Yeah...
(William) Um, I met

Rebecca Black.
(Tommy) Oh, no kidding. And it isn't even Friday.
(credits music)
(William) I'm amazed. Yeah.

(Tommy) What about that blind film critic guy?
(William) Who?
